div.head: Report:
div.p: In the following we report on the first sucessful nuclear scattering experiments at the 23.8795 keV resonance of 'lgSn using both Nuclear Forward Scattering (NFS) and Nuclear Inelastic Scattering (INS) performed by us at ESRF (ID18); 29 shifts in multi-bunch mode and 9 shifts in 16 bund mode. For the high energy resolution monochromator (HRM) we have chosen for the outer channel cut crystal Si(6 4 2) reflection (asymmetric) and symmetric Si(12 12 12) for th e inner channel cut crystal. Fig. l(a) demonstrates the excellent resolution: the energy bandpass of the monochromator was 0.97( 5) meV (FWHM), which corresponds to the relative energy resolution AE/E = 4 . 10m8. This energy resolution is much higher than that reported, e.g. by the Argon group (-3 meV). The time resolution of the detector was about 1.4 ns. Typical count rate at resonance was N 3.5 counts per second (cps) for NFS, at ambient pressure, 6 cps for INS and about 0.3 cps for high pressure NFS test experiments in a Diamond Anvil Cell (DAC). In Fig. l(b) we show first NIS measurements on an enriched (90 % 'lgSn) ,0-S, foil (-8 pm) which clearly show the low energy acustic phonon around 3.5 meV, in an agreement with both inelastic neutron experiments and theoretical prediction. In Fig. 2, 3 and 4 we show collected NFS spectra at 300 K, on simple materials p-Sn and SnS which display no magnetic order. The analysis of the spectra clearly reveals the expected hyperfine interactions in these materials. Most interesting are measurements on UNiSn in the magnetically ordered state (T = 4.2 K) at ambient pressure and at 10 GPa in a DAC. In both cases one observes at Sn a transferred hyperfine field (&f), which originates from the ordering of the U 5f-magnetic moments. Dispite the poor statistics (count rate < 0.3 cps) one can resolve &hf M 7 T at ambient pressure which is in agreement with that known from conventional "'Sn MSssbauer measurements. At 10 GPa Bthf increases to -10 T, indicating the stable moment behavior of U 5f moments in this pressure range.
